briefing.headline: The Stolen Snow Mountain Equipment Case
briefing.narrativeHtml:
Learning Targets for Today:

  • I can use maps to locate snow-covered mountains in Europe
  • I can explain how snow and ice form on tall mountains
  • I can research how people live and work in mountain areas
  • I can identify Alpine countries on a world map
  • I can understand why snow mountains are important for water and farming

Your Mission: Help Sourdough Pete track down Dr. Meridian! She's been stealing weather equipment from mountain weather stations because she's worried about snow melting on European mountains. She thinks she's protecting the environment, but taking things that don't belong to you is wrong! Follow the clues using your maps, globes, and research skills to find her snowy mountain hideout.

What You'll Need: World map, map of Europe, globe, atlas, and internet for research about European mountains and snow

Snow Mountain Detective Challenge: Dr. Meridian loves studying snow, ice, and cold mountain weather. Can you follow her trail through 5 Alpine clues?

suspects.name: Dr. Meridian (Elena Fossat)
suspects.description: A scientist who loves studying snow and ice on tall European mountains. She's so worried about snow melting that she makes bad choices like stealing weather equipment to study mountain climate.

rounds.clueHtml:
Snow Mountain Detective Clue #1:

Dr. Meridian was spotted stealing weather equipment from a snowy mountain! Here's what we know:

  • She's in the famous European mountains that look like giant white teeth pointing up at the sky
  • These mountains are so tall they're covered with snow even in summer!
  • People from all over the world come here to ski, snowboard, and climb mountains
  • The mountains stretch across several countries like Switzerland, France, Austria, and Italy

Your job: Use your maps and globe to find the most famous snow-covered mountains in Europe!
researchPrompts: Look on your Europe map for tall mountain ranges
Find mountains that are covered with snow all year long
Research the Alps mountain range in Europe
Look up which countries have the Alps mountains
expectedProcess: Student examines Europe map for mountain ranges
Student identifies the Alps as major European mountains
Student locates Alps across multiple countries
Student learns that high mountains have permanent snow

reveal.note: Expert at working in cold, high places

rounds.explainHtml:
Great snow mountain detective work! You found the Alps!

The Alps are the most famous mountain range in Europe! They stretch across 8 countries including Switzerland, France, Austria, and Italy. The peaks are so tall (some over 15,000 feet high!) that they stay covered with snow and ice all year long, even when it's hot in summer down in the valleys.

What You Learned:

  • The Alps are Europe's most famous mountain range
  • Very tall mountains stay snowy even in summer
  • Mountain ranges can stretch across many different countries
  • People love to ski and climb in snowy mountains

rounds.clueHtml:
Snow Mountain Detective Clue #2:

Dr. Meridian is now studying mountain snow and ice! Here's what our spy cameras found:

  • She's measuring how much snow falls on the mountains each winter
  • She's worried because less snow is falling than there used to be
  • She's near giant rivers of ice called glaciers that flow down the mountains like super-slow frozen waterfalls
  • These glaciers melt in summer and provide water for people living in the valleys below

Your job: Research how mountain snow and glaciers provide water for people and farms!
researchPrompts: Look up how mountain snow melts to make rivers
Research glaciers - rivers of ice that move very slowly
Find information about how mountains provide water for farming
Look up Alpine glaciers and why they're important
expectedProcess: Student learns that mountain snow melts into rivers
Student discovers glaciers are like frozen rivers
Student understands glaciers provide water for valleys
Student connects mountain water to farming and cities

reveal.trait: Studies snow, ice, and mountain water
reveal.note: Worried about glaciers melting too fast

rounds.explainHtml:
Excellent snow research! You discovered Alpine glaciers!

Glaciers are like giant rivers of ice that flow very slowly down mountains. When snow falls on the Alps year after year, it gets packed down and turns into ice. In summer, some of this ice melts and becomes the water that fills rivers and helps farmers grow food in the valleys below the mountains.

What You Learned:

  • Glaciers are rivers of ice that move very slowly down mountains
  • Mountain snow and ice melt to provide water for rivers
  • People depend on mountain water for drinking and farming
  • Climate change is making glaciers melt faster than before

rounds.clueHtml:
Snow Mountain Detective Clue #3:

Dr. Meridian is now visiting mountain villages! Here's what we discovered:

  • She's talking to people who have lived in the Alps for hundreds of years
  • These mountain people know how to predict weather by watching clouds and wind
  • They build special houses with steep roofs so heavy snow slides off in winter
  • They raise cows and goats that can live in high, cold places and make special mountain cheese

Your job: Research how people live and work in the high Alps mountains!
researchPrompts: Look up how people live in Alpine mountain villages
Research traditional mountain houses with steep roofs
Find information about Alpine farming and mountain animals
Look up Swiss, Austrian, or French mountain culture
expectedProcess: Student researches Alpine mountain communities
Student learns about traditional mountain architecture
Student discovers high-altitude farming techniques
Student understands mountain adaptation strategies

reveal.note: Interested in old mountain knowledge and weather prediction

rounds.explainHtml:
Outstanding mountain culture detective work! You found the Alpine villages!

For hundreds of years, people have lived high in the Alps mountains. They build houses with very steep roofs so snow slides off instead of making the roof collapse. They raise special cows and goats that can survive in cold, high places, and they make delicious cheese from the milk. These mountain people are experts at reading the weather and knowing when storms are coming.

What You Learned:

  • People can live and work in very high, cold mountain areas
  • Mountain houses have steep roofs to shed heavy snow
  • Alpine people raise animals adapted to cold, high places
  • Traditional mountain people are experts at predicting weather

rounds.clueHtml:
Snow Mountain Detective Clue #4:

Dr. Meridian has climbed to her secret weather station! Here's what we know:

  • She's on the tallest mountain in the Alps - the most famous peak in Europe!
  • This mountain is so famous that it has its own name and people come from all over the world to see it
  • It's on the border between France and Italy, and both countries are proud of it
  • Mountain climbers need special training and equipment to reach the top because it's so high and dangerous

Your job: Find the tallest and most famous mountain in the Alps!
researchPrompts: Look up the highest mountain in the Alps
Research the most famous peak in Europe
Find Mont Blanc and its location
Look up mountain climbing in the Alps
expectedProcess: Student researches highest Alps peaks
Student finds Mont Blanc as tallest Alps mountain
Student locates Mont Blanc on France-Italy border
Student learns about mountain climbing challenges

reveal.note: Has weather station on Europe's tallest mountain

rounds.explainHtml:
Incredible mountain detective skills! You found Mont Blanc!

Mont Blanc is the tallest mountain in the Alps at 15,777 feet high! Its name means 'White Mountain' in French because it's always covered with snow and ice. It sits on the border between France and Italy, and both countries consider it their most beautiful mountain. Thousands of people come to see it every year, but only trained mountain climbers with special equipment can reach the snowy summit.

What You Learned:

  • Mont Blanc is the highest mountain in the Alps
  • Very tall mountains are always covered with snow and ice
  • Mountain borders can be shared between countries
  • Mountain climbing requires special training and safety equipment

rounds.clueHtml:
FINAL Snow Mountain Detective Clue:

We found Dr. Meridian's secret plan! She's been setting up a mountain weather education center. Here's her final mission:

  • She wants to teach people that Alpine snow and ice are super important for water supplies
  • Her weather station tracks how much snow falls and how fast glaciers are melting
  • She believes if people understand mountain weather, they'll want to protect the Alps
  • She thinks mountain education can help people take better care of our planet's snow and ice

Final Mission: You've followed Dr. Meridian through her whole Alpine adventure! Put together everything you learned about why snow mountains matter!
researchPrompts: Think about all the mountain places you discovered
Research why mountain snow and ice are important
Look up how the Alps provide water for Europe
Consider how mountains affect weather and climate
expectedProcess: Student reviews all previous mountain clues
Student connects mountain snow to water supplies
Student understands Alpine environmental importance
Student identifies Dr. Meridian's educational mission

reveal.trait: Wants to teach about mountain weather protection
reveal.note: Believes education can help save Alpine snow and ice

rounds.explainHtml:
CASE SOLVED! You caught Dr. Meridian at her mountain education center!

Dr. Meridian wasn't really a bad person - she just cared so much about protecting Alpine snow and ice that she made some wrong choices. She was stealing weather equipment because she wanted to teach people how important mountains are for providing water to Europe. The Alps provide water for rivers, farms, and cities across many countries when the snow and ice melt each spring.

What You Accomplished:

  • You learned to use maps to find famous mountain ranges in Europe
  • You discovered how mountain snow and glaciers provide water
  • You researched how people live and work in high mountain areas
  • You understand why protecting mountain environments is important

Sourdough Pete says: 'Excellent Alpine detective work! You learned that caring about mountain environments is wonderful, but there are right ways and wrong ways to help. Dr. Meridian should have worked with other scientists instead of stealing equipment!'

suspect.name: Dr. Meridian (Elena Fossat)
suspect.notes: Snow mountain lover, weather watcher, ice and snow expert, mountain education teacher

resolution.summaryHtml:
What Students Learned About Snow Mountains:

  • The Alps: Europe's famous snow-covered mountain range across 8 countries
  • Mountain Snow and Ice: Glaciers, permanent snow, and how they provide water
  • Alpine Culture: Mountain villages, traditional houses, high-altitude farming
  • Famous Peaks: Mont Blanc and other tall European mountains
  • Mountain Weather: Why snow mountains are important for water and climate
  • Environmental Protection: How mountain snow and ice help the whole continent
  • Geography Skills: Using maps to find mountain ranges, countries, and peaks

Why This Case Works for 11-Year-Olds:

Age-Appropriate Content: Snow, mountains, skiing, mountain villages, weather watching

Map Skills: European geography, Alps location, country borders, mountain peaks

Educational Progression: Mountain range → snow and ice → mountain people → famous peaks → environmental protection

Real Learning: Geography, climate science, cultural studies, and environmental awareness!
learningExtensions: Learn more about European mountain ranges and their countries
Research how mountain snow provides water for rivers and farms
Study traditional Alpine culture and mountain villages
Explore mountain climbing and high-altitude sports
Learn about glaciers and how they form from snow
Research climate change effects on mountain snow and ice
Study careers in mountain weather forecasting and environmental science
Learn about mountain animals and how they survive in cold, high places
crossCurricular: Geography: European countries, Alps location, mountain borders, elevation
Science: Weather patterns, glaciers, snow formation, climate and elevation
Environmental Studies: Mountain ecosystems, water cycles, environmental protection
Social Studies: Alpine cultures, mountain communities, traditional lifestyles
Math: Mountain heights, distances, temperature changes with elevation
Physical Education: Mountain sports, skiing, hiking, outdoor safety
Art: Drawing mountain landscapes, Alpine architecture, snow and ice scenes
